body:
Use the `:messages` to report errors in decoration providers.

Now on error it works as follows: report to `:messages` and deactivate
the provider for the redraw cycle.

comment_data.body: do we also disable the provider after one (or three, like timer) error messages? otherwise the editor might become unusable due to emsg flood.

As we return false in `decoration_provider_invoke` I'd say that this is not necessary, but maybe we can.

And I'd go with only one error to disable, so that we keep the thing simple.

Better idea. We should add an `on_error` callback and let providers decide on what they want to do?

Default to emsg despite how intrusive it might be.
I'd rather not. This part of the code handles the errors hapenning _within_ a decoration provider, and should thus be handled in core.
That reasoning isn't very clear. The callbacks are implemented by the providers, they have every right to be able to provide a handler for errors.
Not quite because of the newlines, I'll add a new `msg_schedule_semsg_multiline` for that.

comment_regular_data.body:
Should be pretty much ready:
- A decoration provider now gets stopped after 3 consecutive errors (maybe we can make that configurable ?)
- The errors are reported into the messages.
I assume the provider is activated when calling `nvim_set_decoration_provider` again? Then I think this is good to go.

That's a good question, it should follow the normal "reset" of the decoration provider, thus reactivating it.

I'd suggest getting @lewis6991 opinion on this change, as we could not quite agree on the approach to take here.

My high level opinion is that a "one size fits all" approach is going to be hard. Ideally a provider should have a choice, whether that be:

- hard error every time
- do nothing (ignore all errors)
- disable the provider for the current cycle
- disable the provider completely
- report and error once (or N times) but keep the provider active
- soft report the error into an internal log away from the user 

For different applications In mind:

- Gitsigns.nvim: hard error once but continue to log errors internally but keep the provider active

- TS highlighter: soft error (via messages) and disable for the current cycle
To make progress on this, I'm happy to accept the PR as is and require applications to use `pcall` if they wish to implement specific error handling.

I don't think we need to be smart here; a solution that works for treesitter without breaking other current behavior is fine.

A lower hanging fruit would be to just replace the end-of-line virtual text by virtual line(s); as long as the full error message is no longer made useless by the cut off, that's all I care about.
Work is already done, and tested 😉
